awd_titl_txt: Harnessing Nitrogen Vacancy Centers for Hybrid Quantum Information Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Currently much progress has been witnessed in the quantum-information technologies. The emerging quantum information applications serve as a transformative operation platform enabling an unprecedented data storage volume, processing speed, parallelization, as well as robust strategies against random and malignant perturbations. Many of those advantages derive from their quantum-mechanical nature endowed by excellent quantum coherence, controllable entanglement, and high fidelity of operations, which enable opportunities for outperforming their classical counterparts. Known as single-spin quantum bits, nitrogen vacancy centers, optically-active atomic defects in diamond, are known for their intrinsically long coherence time, single-spin addressability, and notable versatility in a broad temperature range, offering remarkable opportunities in designing multifunctional quantum-information systems.  This proposal aims to integrate nitrogen vacancy centers with functional spintronic devices to develop hybrid quantum architectures, providing opportunities to develop nitrogen-vacancy-based quantum computers. The proposed research project will promote the participation of a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students from physics and engineering departments and outreach activities will include lectures and demos to nearby high schools and community colleges.  The proposed research and education activities will increase the society’s awareness in material science and quantum information technologies.

The goal of this study is to address the major challenges facing quantum-computing with nitrogen vacancy centers by electrically manipulating the quantum spin states of nitrogen vacancy centers via the localized microwave magnetic fields generated by spin-torque nano-oscillators. By introducing the single-magnon mode sustained by a one-dimensional magnetic coupler, macroscale entanglement between distant nitrogen vacancy spin qubits can be established. The mutual interaction between spin-torque nano-oscillators and nitrogen vacancy centers can be controlled in a scalable fashion down to a sub-micrometer regime, which significantly improves the scalability of nitrogen vacancy centers in developing quantum electronic devices. By developing nitrogen-vacancy-magnon-based hybrid quantum systems and demonstrating their operation in an ambient environment, it is proposed a compatible, solid-state-based quantum-operation platform, which can be conveniently extended to the on-chip devices. It is expected new opportunities will emerge for designing high-density, scalable quantum memory and significantly promote the role of nitrogen vacancy centers in developing next-generation quantum technologies. The study will also elucidate the intriguing science of spin-torque nano-oscillators. Nitrogen vacancy centers will provide information to access the underlying spin transport and dynamic behaviors in nano-spintronic systems and provide guidelines to design advanced magnetic materials to improve the performance of spintronic electronics for future transformative information technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major focus of this proposal is to integrate nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers with functional spintronic devices to develop NV-magnon-based hybrid systems to improve the solid-state scalability and density of NVs for large scale quantum information science and technological applications. Our stretch goal is to introduce propagating single-magnon mode(s) sustained by a one-dimensional magnetic channel to establish quantum entanglement between distant NV centers, advancing the development of NV-based quantum-computing platforms.

Over the past four years (including the one-year no-cost extension), we have achieved the following achievements under this award.

Intellectual Merit: We demonstrated coherent manipulation of a single NV center and NV ensembles by spatially confined magnetic stray fields produced by a proximal resonant magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ). At the present technological level, one of the major challenges for designing NV-based hybrid systems for quantum innovations results from the difficulty of realizing local control of individual NV spin qubits in a scalable and energy-efficient way. We introduce MTJ devices to establish electrically driven coherent coupling between an NV center and a resonant MTJ with voltage controlled magnetic anisotropy. We show that the oscillating magnetic stray field produced by a resonant micromagnet can be utilized to effectively modify and drive coherent NV spin rotations when the NV electron spin resonance frequency matches the corresponding resonant conditions of the MTJ (Fig. 1 and Fig. 2). The coherent coupling between NV center(s) and the MTJ can be symmetrically controlled by a bias voltage, allowing for appreciable electrical tunability in the presented hybrid system (Fig. 3). Due to the large electrical resistance of the insulating tunnel layer of the MTJ devices, the magnitude of microwave electric currents flowing through the pillar junction is in the microampere regime, virtually eliminating ohmic losses and the resulting thermal decoherence of proximal NV centers. We also develop NV-magnetic-insulator-based hybrid system and utilized spin currents generated by spin Hall effect to achieve tuning of Gilbert damping and the amplitude of dipole fields generated by a micrometer-sized Y3Fe5O12 pattern, demonstrating electrical control of NV Rabi oscillation frequency in a quantum spintronic system (Fig. 4).

Broader Impact: Besides the scientific achievements discussed above, this project also has exerted a broad impact on education, training of graduate/undergraduate students and outreach programs to increase society’s awareness of some of the most exciting development in material science and quantum technologies. 1). The principal investigator (PI) worked closely with the Center for Research on Educational Equity, Assessment & Teaching Excellence (CREATE) at UC San Diego to foster the participation of underrepresented minority (URM) groups in the STEM community. Students obtained first-hand training experiences on performing quantum sensing, electrical transport, and nanodevice fabrications in the PI's lab. 2) the PI hosted two undergraduate students from Mexico to participate summer research projects through a bi-national program. During the six-week internship period, the PI and her group members introduced ample research opportunities for the undergraduates to learn quantum optics, two-dimensional materials, color centers, and atomic force microscopy measurements. 3) the PI participated in the NSF-supported Cal-Bridge mentoring program and advised two students from URM groups to apply for physics Ph. D. program. It is a high pleasure to share the news that a female URM student advised by the PI received Ph.D. offers from top research universities in the United States and now has started her exciting Ph.D. career.

2. J. Zhou, G. Yan, M. Huang, N. J. McLaughlin, C. H. R. Du, and H. L. Wang, Quantum sensing of local stray field environment of micron-scale magnetic disks, Appl. Phys. Lett. 123, 024003 (2023).

3. G. Q. Yan, S. Li, T. Yamamoto, M. Huang, N. J. McLaughlin, T. Nozaki, H. L. Wang, S. Yuasa, and C. H. R. Du, Electric-Field-Induced Coherent Control of Nitrogen Vacancy Centers, Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 064031 (2022).

4. G. Q. Yan et al., Quantum Sensing and Imaging of Spin-orbit-torque-driven Spin Dynamics in Noncollinear Antiferromagnet Mn3Sn, Adv. Mater. 34, 2200327 (2022).

5. E. Lee-Wong, J. Ding, X. Wang, C. Liu, N. J. McLaughlin, H. L. Wang, M. Wu, and C. H. R. Du, Quantum Sensing of Spin Fluctuations of Magnetic Insulator Films with Perpendicular Anisotropy, Phys. Rev. Appl. 15, 034031 (2021).

6.  X. Wang, Y. Xiao, C. Liu, E. Lee-Wong, N. Mclaughlin, H. Wang, H. L. Wang, M. Wu, E. E. Fullerton, and C. H. R. Du, Electrical Control of Coherent Spin Rotation of a Single-Spin Qubit, npj Quantum Inf. 6, 78 (2020).
